description:
But first the latest emergency summit of Eurozone leaders has ended with another deadline for the Greek government to present a workable bailout proposal to its creditors. The European Council President Donald Tusk said Athens had two more days to come up with the plan to solve its debt crisis and added that the situation was so grave that all 28 EU leaders would meet to try to finalise a deal on Sunday. The meetings in Brussels were called after the people of Greece voted in a referendum on Sunday against the terms of an international bailout. Our correspondent Katya Adler is in Brussels and she told us what will happen next.

"There is talk tonight that there is a short-term deal on the table. The idea would be to keep Greece afloat long enough as to be able then to hammer out a longer-term deal. If confirmed, this will be dismissed by many as typical EU kicking the can down the road. But positive and negative, today has been another day of mixed messages in Greece. And if the noises coming from Eurozone leaders sound confused, that is because that's what they are. They are confused. They are frustrated. They are dismayed. There's never been a situation like this. No Eurozone country has ever acted with such defiance towards its creditors. No Eurozone country has ever teetered this close to falling out of the single currency. "
